A very decent amount of contents for the price. The game is casual friendly but has higher difficulty settings if you want to apply the mechanics. 

Overall, the narrative is more of a draw than the combat mechanics. It does a fairly decent job at "modernizing" the wuxia genre. I think what stands out the most is that it incorporate more nuanced character development that do not necessarily serve the classic wuxia tropes. Some elements were certainly borrowed from anime and JRPG and they bring the story to a new height.

The fictional world in which the game takes place does have numerous real life history references if you are familiar with East Asian history. What I really like about this narrative is that it significantly toned down the Sinocentrism in a lot of the classic wuxia that created a fake duality of "good south vs evil north". This game takes a much more humanistic approach to the classic understanding of the wuxia world. Wuxia as a genre has the cold war era precedence of being hijacked by Chinese ethnonationalism (some of which were understandable metaphorical reactions from Hongkong/Taiwan authors against mainland Communists), and most modern wuxia stories still follow the same mold. This game breaks that mold by taking a rather pragmatic and fair stance by giving almost all characters a fair shake. In fact, I was drawn to the game immediately when I learned that the protagonist's name is likely a geopolitical reference to the historical Northern Asia. And I was not disappointed by the author's somewhat fair treatment.

The one downside I will mention is that the numerous endings require very detailed instructions to reach, likely not possible without a guide, and very time consuming. But obviously you can just watch recordings of those endings.

Either way, highly recommend if you are used to old wuxia and would like a more dynamic modern take.

One-line verdict:
A flawless 10/10 experience—and an absolute must-play for anyone who loves the wuxia genre.

This game is an absolute masterpiece within the wuxia category. The only real rival it has is Hero's Adventure, and since both titles use different mechanics—despite being turn-based—they complement each other wonderfully and can be enjoyed side by side.

For new players, I highly recommend using an online companion guide during your first playthrough. It helps ensure you don’t miss any recruitable companions or key pieces of lore and story that make the experience what it truly is.

It's a wuxia story involving many of the places, factions and concepts familiar to those familiar with the genre (fantastical martial arts, sects devoted to such, the struggle between good & evil and the like). A 'Zero to Hero' kind of story  as such.

- There are plenty of places to travel to, many interesting personages to seek, lots of secrets both big and small to find out...

- I would compare this game to 'Hero's Adventure' as well as the first two Baldur's Gate games - though it's a bit more linear than Heros Adventure (so, more like BG 1&2 there), you may be surprised by how many things can affect the story in both small and big ways. Which brings me to another point:

- What I think is remarkable about the game is how it encourages the player to be thorough. Doing not just the main quest but also side-quests, making sure to check things thoroughly during the quests, travelling far and wide unprompted during your playthrough, searching every every nook and cranny... Doing these tend to reward the player with extra good stuff, unlock new companions, unlocking new solutions for future quests and even later future outcomes and events of the course of the game's story... It's something that makes the game enjoyable for me and also gives the player a reason to replay it.

- While the game is categorized as an RPG, it should be said that you shouldn't expect too much from it in that regard. Yes, there are some aspects of the main character you can control, such as their choice of weapon styles and in some cases which matters they choose to get involved with or not and the like, but... Not that many; if that's a plus or minus is for you to decide, I guess.

- Many games in this genre are badly or so-so translated or not translated too... Coherently as such, but this seems to be very well done indeed and you should find little to nothing to complain about in this regard.

- Although this game is advertised  as turn-based, there's a choice to go from turn-based to realtime, but it's not an option I choose to explore, so can't comment on it other than that it exists if you prefer that over turn-based.

- The art is nice, both in terms of pixels and the character designs and whatnot.

Overall: This may well be the best or at least one of the best wuxia games you could possibly add to your collection! Very much recommended for fans of the genre, and even if you aren't a fan, I recommend trying it!

Wandering Sword is a difficult game to recommend, but at the same time it's really something that needs to be played to understand and appreciate it. The game is very unique when compared to the standard RPG fare. It's growth and progression systems are entirely different, the way it handles it's story and characters is closer to a SaGa game in feel, the graphics are very Octopath like in design but with it's own flair, the music is pretty damn good, and it's quests and their end states have more layers than an onion varying. There is a metric ton of stuff to unpack in this game and it's clearly been designed with multiple play throughs in mind from the word "go"

Combat is a tactical grid based affair once you run into an enemy. All the different martial arts and weapon moves you've acquired have a fixed range and different effects. At game's start you are going to feel like a chump. The story also intentionally pits you against and allies you with stronger martial artists early on in the story just to drive the point home how much weaker you are than them. But it does this for a reason. It wants you to feel weak so you strive to better yourself and Yuwen Yi as a character through his personal journey, and good lord what a journey it is. Conspiracy, betrayal, the strong trying to subjugate the weak, allies, scheming, evil, there's a lot of familiar elements here but where the game shines is in it's overall Wuxia theme. The developers clearly have a passion for the genre that's hard to describe and the work and care that was put into this game shows.

But that is also a double edged sword for this game. As interesting as Wuxia is as a theme it's subject matter is a bit dense. Some of the terminology and details can be a little overwhelming at first and this might turn people off early into the game. The basic overarching story isn't hard to grasp there's just a whole lot of words used to tell it backed by concepts that a westerner might be unfamiliar with. But honestly it's a minor problem in the end. If you can get through the first couple of hours without losing interest I'd argue the game has done it's job. I also want to point out that while the translation isn't perfect compared to other games whose native language is Chinese this is one amazing translation.

About the only other thing I can really hold against the game is two fold. The Secrets of the Eastern Sea DLC while good isn't very well balanced. The skills and some of the items you can acquire are pretty dang broken when taken back into the main game. Which is really too bad because the extra lore, story, and character details the DLC adds are wonderful. The other minor complaint I have is that controller support is a little "janky" It's very clear that this game was designed to be played with M/KB and that controller support was added as almost an after thought. It works well enough but it has some strange little quirks that might take some getting used to. I can't really think of anything else to complain about. I suppose things in the story being easy to miss, or characters being hard to recruit, and the like might bug some people but you have over 30 auto saves and can generally save anywhere. All you're really losing is time in that case.

But seriously this game is fantastic on a lot of levels. There is easily 100+ hours worth of content here if you're willing to take your time. And it's not like the price is going to break the bank unlike some current "AAA" titles might. If you're looking for something different in regards to the RPGs you play Wandering Sword is about as different as it gets. Highly recommended but do your research first.

I'll be honest.  Initially, I played this game because of the cast of pretty boys.  But then it became something more.

I'm GENUINELY obsessed with this game.  I've never dipped my toes into the wuxia genre much, but this game made me want to learn more about martial arts and Chinese culture!  Like, I want to make a discord about this!

Pros:

The best parts are the beginning to middle story arcs as they're very strong and engaging.  the final arcs felt rushed somehow, but then again, I was playing the latest update that included the Southern Chronicles DLC.  If you want to play the original story and go for a more bittersweet journey painted with tragedy and redemption, opt out of the golden scorpion quests that initiate it.

Yuwen Yi is a great protagonist and he undergoes amazing character development throughout the story based on your choices.  He starts out as close to an audience surrogate if you're not familiar with martial arts.  I was expecting to play as someone already hard-boiled and alienated by living as a martial artist.  Yuwen Yi is endearing, loyal, kind to a fault, and naive starting out, but it's rewarding to see him grow and mature into a powerful martial artist that you train him to be.

Beautiful world, gorgeous art, and there's many funny scenes - mostly having to do with Bai Jin.

The many, many cast of characters you get to meet and recruit!  They're all interesting in their own right.

Gameplay-wise, it gets repetitive sometimes and you definitely have to grind sometimes.  Luckily, there's two modes you can play: turn-based or real time.  It's fun to switch it up!  On the other hand, if you're like me and hate grinding for hours, there's always the auto option.

Cons:

Sometimes the game gets glitchy during battles.  I don't know why.  It lags, but maybe that's because I need a new graphics card.

This game is definitely BRUTAL without a guide.  I played mostly blind until I realized how much content I was missing just by progressing too deep into the main storyline and then being too past the point of return to recruit those three characters crucial to obtaining a good ending. Limited love interests.

Okay, so don't get me wrong.  I absolutely have no problem with Yao Ji and Ouyang Xue.  Both are sweethearts in their own ways and the way they fall in love with Yuwen Yi is natural and lovely to see if you prefer them.  But I feel like the whole the "girl next door" and "dating catwoman" shtick has been done so many times that I've lost my taste for it.  As far as the official romance options go, they're both alright, I guess.  Their illustrations and sprites are beautiful.  Just not my cup of tea.  I sympathize with Yao Ji seeing her tragic background and hard life in the cult, and she's pretty badass with the flame sabers, so I can give her that much credit.  As for Ouyang Xue, she's nice.  But that's pretty much it.  I personally don't find her character compelling as it feels like she was only really there to support Yuwen Yi and didn't have any strong personal goals of her own besides Yuwen Yi.  Like a love satellite.  But I do commend her for being more proactive and her badassery upgrade in the Southern Chronicles, even though she still felt ultimately sidelined in contrast to the other characters.

However!  In my personal opinion (and this is just my opinion, so if you don't agree with me that's fine please don't attack me), I feel that seeing as so much content was devoted to Shangguan Hong (best girl besides Bu Weiyue and Yia Vang) to the point of giving her new clothes, an awesome sword, and considerable focus in numerous cutscenes, I'm shocked the developers didn't just make her the third official romance option, considering she's journeyed with Yuwen Yi the entire time (if you find her) and has her feelings hinted at several times in the game.  Suma Ling is like their hyperactive little sister/child, lol.  Though I can understand if this was meant to be write them in a more platonic familial light.

Like, how can you get an ending with Xiaotong but no Shangguan Hong?!  She was done dirty, I swear.

Yia Vang.  The Scorpion Envoy!  OMG I looove her :sob: She's nothing but sweet and helpful.  I'm not just saying this because I'm biased towards her exotic design.  She's absolutely killing the scorpion motif.  I really wish she could've been romanced as a secret romance option or something.  It'd've been amazing since Vang is from the Wuxian sect and they could've connected more based off their association with Xiaotong.  Idk if she has a hidden ending, but I know that Shangguang Hong and Frosty Condor and Xun Yaoyao have hidden endings if maxing out their affection.

She WOULD be my favorite if she'd've been a love interest!  But she's not, so the winner goes to...

Bu Weiyue is the best girl, hands down.  Pretty islander girl with monkey sidekick ftw!  She's already powerful when you meet her, but the assets she provides are really helpful for the player, especially for a new game + playthrough.

The fact that there's no official solo ending reserved for her like there is for Ouyang Xue and Yao Ji makes me salty to this day.  Girl literally shows up out of nowhere, trolls the men trying to take advantage of her and makes them run away without their clothes, and gives Yuwen Yi his own island, an awesome fan that deals damage, and has the best chemistry with him out of all the main official love interests.  She's so quirky, cute, and genuine and can relate to Yuwen the most.  She's the last part of the Yuwen-Shangguang-Sima troop.  The DLC arc of them overcoming trials and becoming closer throughout the journey was really natural and sweet, especially the romantic scenes at night.  I feel like her romance with Yuwen Yi felt the most natural, supportive, and romantically endearing since they spend a lot of time together.  Watching her gradually fall in love with him was adorable while Yuwen stumbling and stammering around her was pretty cute to see as well.

The monkey is pretty much their child, lol.

Plus, her confession scene was actually really beautiful and sweet.  How could I say no!  I admire her boldness for sure.

Overall rating:

8.2/10

It definitely stands out as a wuxia RPG, and the characters and story are compelling and solid enough to keep you playing.  However, sometimes it's more of a "tell" rather than "show" narrative.  Characters throw a lot of lore and exposition at the player out of nowhere, which can make it hard to follow/exhausting.

Beginning to mid was strong - but the last few arcs felt shaky and rushed.  I felt the execution could've been more gradual instead of flinging villain group after villain group to reach the resolution.  The villain valley guys were introduced as threatening, powerful enemies, only to get cut down pretty unceremoniously at the end.  They didn't get much development and focus besides the two secret enemies who I wont' say or else I'll end up spoiling them.  Basically, the main villains were there to be all imposing and threatening but don't have as much substance to them as say, the traitor antagonists.

The later plot twists I saw coming from a while away, and they weren't executed too well in my opinion.  It was alright.  Not bad, but not great either.

Still, the bromance between Yuwen Yi and his other companions was endearing to watch.  Bai Win is who I consider Yuwen's closest bestie.  My alcoholic dude is so chill and gives no fucks whatsoever about the sects or world.  My man just wants his drink.  It would've been hilarious if he'd been a love interest.

All in all, I had a lot of fun playing this game!  I really enjoyed the martial arts/wuxia aspect, which is different from most RPG games I play.  So definitely try it!

What a journey it's been. If you're a fan of the Wuxia theme, I ABSOLUTELY recommend this masterpiece of a game. If I were a little less poor, I'd have bought this game for my friends so they can experience this journey as well.

LOOOONG review ahead so be warned:



In terms of story, if you're familiar with this theme in general, you'll be familiar with a lot of the tropes present in the game. The story had me hooked from start to end, and I always felt that I gotta keep going and do more. Even the side quests are fun enough with their own compelling stories.

Progression feels amazing and extremely immersive; that zero-to-hero feeling feels hard-earned as every skill, every cultivation technique, everything you do contributes to the overall growth of your character. A very decent amount of contents for the price. The game is casual friendly but has higher difficulty settings if you want to apply the mechanics. 

Overall, the narrative is more of a draw than the combat mechanics. It does a fairly decent job at "modernizing" the wuxia genre. I think what stands out the most is that it incorporate more nuanced character development that do not necessarily serve the classic wuxia tropes. Some elements were certainly borrowed from anime and JRPG and they bring the story to a new height.

The fictional world in which the game takes place does have numerous real life history references if you are familiar with East Asian history. What I really like about this narrative is that it significantly toned down the Sinocentrism in a lot of the classic wuxia that created a fake duality of "good south vs evil north". This game takes a much more humanistic approach to the classic understanding of the wuxia world. Wuxia as a genre has the cold war era precedence of being hijacked by Chinese ethnonationalism (some of which were understandable metaphorical reactions from Hongkong/Taiwan authors against mainland Communists), and most modern wuxia stories still follow the same mold. This game breaks that mold by taking a rather pragmatic and fair stance by giving almost all characters a fair shake. In fact, I was drawn to the game immediately when I learned that the protagonist's name is likely a geopolitical reference to the historical Northern Asia. And I was not disappointed by the author's somewhat fair treatment.

The one downside I will mention is that the numerous endings require very detailed instructions to reach, likely not possible without a guide, and very time consuming. But obviously you can just watch recordings of those endings.

Either way, highly recommend if you are used to old wuxia and would like a more dynamic modern take.

This game is awesome. Amazing value for money. It's like 8 excellent martial arts movies in one. The writing is hammy, but in a fun and charming way, and the plot is soooo goooood. The villains are cartoonish but believable and compelling.  The DEVs have been attentive to irritations, like they have a 'skip minigame' option, an autopilot function for grinding trash mobs of enemies, and the game (usually) warns you when you're about to do something stupid. I hope there are many more RPGs and similar in the Wuxia world. This is more of an adventure game than an RPG, but it rocks either way. 

My only significant grievance was that the quests and their triggers weren't signposted well in many cases, so it's pretty easy to miss really important sidequests, like to recruit the Killing Precept monk and Frosty Condor (I got that one but I had to replay about 4 hours). This reminded me of games like chrono trigger that this game is obviously inspired by, but this is something people do not remember fondly about those games. Basically every time the "main quest" flag gets updated you should make a hard save and then go to every location on the map and talk to everybody, or use a guide (but I was using guides a bit and still missed stuff, and there aren't many complete/good guides).

Another small grievance is that with the two big updates and the DLC, the power curve is now out of whack and you need to self-handicap or switch to extreme difficulty half way. The fan powers in the DLC especially are basically broken (though very hard to get before about two thirds of the way through), especially Immortal's Descent which makes all the boss battles a cakewalk. I'd leave it until right before the very late duel on the snowy mountain unless you want to feel like none of the epic battles are especially epic. The Elusive Swordplay technique in the Nanjiang arc is similarly absurd. If you're a completionist and you upgrade forging, tailoring, and your skills as you go along combat will be very boring by midgame. Combat is generally not so deep, but just enjoying being an overpowered Wuxia! 

Speaking of which, as other people have noted, the way the game/story responds to your increasing power is super satisfying and well crafted. At the start of the game people are mocking you but you persist heroically. In the middle people are like "We should be careful, I've heard this guy is strong". And by the end everyone is like "oh shit we about to get stomped". It feels good. The levelling up is generally subtle until you get a few busted moves too early. If you refrain from using Red Moves, perhaps except for Tai Chi, until at least the Nanjiang arc, and refrain from the fan skills entirely, you should be fine.

The upgrades, stats and inventory are by far my least favourite parts of this game.  Upgrades never feel meaningful outside of increasing numbers.  There was never a turning point where it felt like I unlocked a game-changing ability or feat, rather it felt like box ticking. The layout of the UI, even in combat, for these is bad.  Any time you hover your mouse to see details, it covers half of the inventory or action bar, with no option in game settings to reduce or customise it in any form.  The stats are rarely explained, and the tutorial log doesn't offer much insight.  I had to google a lot of the terms to see what I was pumping points into.  

Gold is practically useless outside of crafting, yet you're flooded with it from the start with a big welcoming chest in your inventory.  You'll come across way higher level items than you have equipped but with far worse stats for some reason.  XP gain doesn't even seem to do anything for some of the abilities.  I looked up what gathering and fishing XP does and the only thing I found was from the developers apologising in a community thread in 2023 because they apparently don't do anything.

I'm pretty disappointed given the overall user reviews for this when the game - in my opinion - needs a lot of work done to scratch that RPG/adventure itch.  If this were a fraction of the price or still in early access I think I would still recommend it for future reference, because the developers clearly have a lot of talent, but - my two cents - they need to continue to work on these problems to be worth your time and money.
